activity_b.text: What’s the required width of this access platform? It is 666 cm. But this access platform is only 575 cm wide at the moment. This access platform is 91 cm too narrow for safe movement.
What’s the required height of this storage roof? It is 4,200 mm. But this storage roof is only 3,950 mm high. This storage roof is 250 mm too low for the required clearance.
What’s the required length of this ceiling frame? It is 37 m. But this ceiling frame is only 34 m long in the current layout. This ceiling frame is 3 m too short for this warehouse.

What’s the required thickness of this protective steel sheet? It is 18 mm. But this protective steel sheet is only 14 mm thick on inspection. This protective steel sheet is 4 mm too thin for reinforcement.
What’s the required capacity of this fuel reservoir? It is 8,500 litres. But this fuel reservoir was only 7,900 litres full this morning. This fuel reservoir was 600 litres too low for operation.
What’s the required pressure in this distribution pipeline? It is 288 bar. But this distribution pipeline is only at 256 bar right now. This distribution pipeline is 32 bar too low for normal flow.

What’s the required voltage for this electrical supply line? It is 415 volts. But this electrical supply line is only at 384 volts under load. This electrical supply line is 31 volts too low for equipment start-up.
What’s the required temperature in this curing chamber? It is 920°C. But this curing chamber is only at 870°C on the display. This curing chamber is 50°C too cold for correct treatment.
What’s the required diameter of this ventilation duct? It is 980 mm. But this ventilation duct is only 900 mm wide in the new section. This ventilation duct is 80 mm too narrow for proper airflow.
What’s the required speed of this conveyor drive unit? It is 1440 rpm. But this conveyor drive unit is only at 1320 rpm when operating. This conveyor drive unit is 120 rpm too slow for production.

activity_b.text: Yesterday was honestly hectic in the Mechanical Technology workshop.
We serviced several training machines in the new practical bay near the stores.
It wasn’t a small task.
There were  a lathe machine, a milling machine, a hydraulic press, and the air compressor running at the same time.
The work was demanding, but the workshop is secure now, and that’s what matters.
Everyone felt the pressure, but we finished the job.
So, how did you feel doing your first full maintenance task?
To be honest, it was tougher than I expected.
There are many steps to follow, and you can’t skip any of them.
First, the job sheet wasn’t very clear, so that was confusing.
Then some tools weren’t in the right place, and one spanner set was incomplete.
The measurements were correct later, but in the morning they were off.
Adjusting the lathe parameters was not easy.
I aligned the tailstock, checked the chuck, and cleaned the bed.
A few bolts were loose, and that caused some vibration.
The machine wasn’t safe at first, so we stopped it.
Yes, planning is everything in mechanical work.
If the alignment is wrong, the whole operation becomes unsafe.
The lubrication system was mostly fine, but one oil line was blocked.
That  was fixable.
It was quite tense once the machines were running.
The checks were strict, and everyone stayed focused.
We all knew that there was no room for mistakes.
After the final inspection, the machines were smooth and stable.
The noise level is normal now, and the vibration is low.
Not every adjustment was perfect, but the setup meets the standards.
Today, the workshop is much quieter.
There’s no heavy operation going on.
This morning we are cleaning tools and checking safety guards only.
Next week, you’re going to assemble a test unit and record performance data.
Sounds good.
Next time, we’re going to prepare better.
Now we know what works, what fails, and how to solve problems faster.
